text: James Braid (1795 - 1860) was a Scottish surgeon and hypnotist.Alan Gauld, ‘Braid, James (1795–1860)’, Oxford Dictionary of National Biography, Oxford University Press, 2004 , , accessed 29 Dec 2015. He was born in Portmoak, Scotland. He died in of an illness in Chorlton-on-Medlock, Manchester. ==Research on hypnotism== Braid saw a demonstration of mesmerism by Charles Lafontaine in 1841 and began to explore and research the subject for himself. He argued that the trance like state that a person went into, which he called hypnotism, was a state of mind. He said it was not caused by the transferring "mesmeric fluid" or "animal magnetism". He believed a hypnotic state could be caused by having a person stare at a small bright object. When a person was in a hypnotic state, they could be given suggestions which they did not remember when fully awake. He also noted changes in pulse and blood circulation, which he believed were able to cure some illnesses. He began using hypnotism and suggestion as way of treating some of his patients. His ideas were later developed by a group of doctors in Paris, who were called "Braidists". Led by the neurologist J. M. Charcot, their work made it scientifically acceptable to study hypnotism. ==Books and articles== Braid wrote a book and several articles about his research and his ideas: * Neurypnology, or, The Rationale of Nervous Sleep (1843). * The Power of the Mind over the Body (1846). * Magic, Witchcraft, Animal Magnetism, Hypnotism, and Electro-Biology (1852). * Hypnotic Therapeutics, Illustrated by Cases (1853). ==References== Category:1795 births Category:1860 deaths Category:British neurologists Category:Scottish scientists Category:Scottish medical doctors
